repnme.cdata!:
Lebanon - Emergency Power Sector Reform
            Capacity Reinforcement Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Emergency Power Sector
            Reform Capacity Reinforcement Project for Lebanon were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory; risk to
            development outcome was substantial; Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory and borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: the
            Bank's entering strategy into sensitive political
            topics in complex environments should be carefully
            scrutinized. Being transparent and earning buy-in from
            stakeholders on the reform process is essential: if the
            final industrial structure is not defined ex ante, the
            restructuring assessment should be inclusive of all
            stakeholders to succeed. If one aims at important power
            sector reforms, having a clear and explicit understanding of
            the political economy challenges is essential to understand
            who the winners and losers behind the reform are.

13818199.trustfund:
TF058084-EMERGENCY POWER SECTOR REFORM
            CAPACITY REINFORCEMENT PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
Lebanon - Emergency Power Sector Reform
            Capacity Reinforcement Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Emergency Power
            Sector Reform Capacity Reinforcement Project for Lebanon is
            to accelerate the implementation of electricity sector
            reforms and restructuring of Electricite du Leban (EdL) by
            enhancing the capacity of Ministry of Environment and Waters
            (MOEW), EdL and the multi-ministry higher level committee.
            To date the project has funded three consulting contracts
            that have supported the Lebanese government with the
            capacity to implement reforms to the electricity sector.
            However, one of these consulting contracts has not been
            completed due to lack of political consensus around
            recommendations made by the consultants. The Government of
            Lebanon therefore intends to terminate this contract and
            using remaining project funds to fund further consulting
            services to support implementation of much needed
            electricity sector reforms. This restructuring paper
            proposes a second extension to the closing date of this
            project from December 31, 2010 to December 31, 2012 to allow
            the project to be completed and to meet its original project
            development objectives.

display_title.display_title:
Lebanon - Emergency Power Sector
            Reform Capacity Reinforcement Project : restructuring (Vol.
            2) : Data sheet
